NOTE: This is a review of Half-Life in the world of 2014.
Is this game worth playing still? Unfortunately, it has not held the test of time.

While Half-Life may have been revolutionary when released, the lack of any coherent plot, repetative play, and terrible level design (seriously, there's one hallway in and out of any room in this facility) compared to modern FPS's makes this a dull play in 2014. There's no reason to play it now, unless you want to be nostolgic or prefer lifeless FP shooters.

舞台は我々とは異なる時間軸の2000年代の5月ごろ。
MITで博士課程を修了し、オーストリアで研究をしていた若手物理学者ゴードン・フリーマン。
この度アメリカ合衆国ニューメキシコ州にある巨大研究所ブラックメサに赴任した青年である。
この研究所は放射線、ロケット工学、理論物理学、推進装置、水理学、ロボット工学、生命工学、
動物学、応用数学などありとあらゆる分野の研究者が集まる最先端科学研究の場だ。
フリーマンはこの研究所に勤務する恩師の紹介でレベル3寄宿舎に引っ越し、
ブラックメサ・セクター3研究施設で職務を遂行しながら研究生活を送ることになったのである。

フリーマンらの仕事は反重力分光計に未知の物質を挿入して何が起こるのか調べることだ。
しかし今日に限ってコンピュータシステムの重大な障害、実験室制御装置の破損と不吉なトラブルが続く。
漂う不安ムードの中、フリーマンは高性能防護服「HEV対有害環境防護スーツ」を纏い反重力分光計実験室の中へ入っていく・・・。

In E3 1997, A small and new company called Valve Corp. had shown their first title Half-Life 1 and immediately took the position for the best game at E3. In 1998 Sierra Entertainment and Valve Corp. released Half Life 1 (goldsrc) for the public. It took over 50 game of the year awards and spun off two expansions and many mods such as Counter-Strike developed by Minh Le and Jess Cliff. Now 16 years later in 2014 despite of it's outdated graphics, Half-Life is still played by the millions. And for those who wonder why Gordon dosen't/can't speak is because Valve wanted the feel that YOU are Gordon and YOU are in the game and not another soul. I hope this game still lasts as long as Steam lasts.

Valve Corporation’s debut smash hit, Half-Life, spelled the doom of Boomer Shooters as the dominant market force in FPS games upon its release in 1998. Prior to Half-Life’s release, the genre was dominated by the id Software franchises Doom and Quake, with the games that they inspired carving out the remainder of the market share. Story in video games was often seen as unimportant or unnecessary past the base justification of the player’s actions. Half-life changed the landscape of video games as a whole with its focus on introducing abundant atmosphere, an engaging story, and tactical depth to the pre-established expectations of first person shooters at the time.

	Half-Life's intent to immerse the player in a living world is apparent from the opening scene of the game. The player avatar, a scientist working for the Black Mesa Research Facility who we later learn is named Gordan Freeman, rides a tram system from his dormitory to his place of work. As the ride progresses, we see evidence of the laissez faire attitude of the Black Mesa administration to the safety procedures practiced onsite. An automatic announcement system blairs over the speakers on the tram, warning personnel to report any suspected exposure to radiation as the monorail rides over a lake of radioactive waste. Ambient drones echo in the player’s ears as they cross over deep underground pits with no visible bottom. Researchers in the labs are terse and uninterested in conversation while analyzing formulas on whiteboards or inputting data into spreadsheets. This tense, foreboding atmosphere only grows heavier throughout the game, making the player feel like a rat trapped without hope of escape, tone weighing down on them like all the tons of rock overhead.

	Such an atmosphere lends itself well to the story of the game. Gordon is scheduled for a test on anomalous materials and suits up in the now iconic Hazardous Environments Suit featured on the boxart. Once protected, he travels to the test site where equipment malfunctions have been creating minor disturbances all day. Despite these malfunctions, the site administrator has been promised results and the test goes on without delay. This results in an apocalyptic disaster called a Resonance Cascade that weakens the barrier between our reality and the borderworld Xen, unleashing alien monstrosities that quickly begin slaughtering the staff. Immediately after awakening from the injuries he sustained during the test, Gordan’s only goal becomes escape from the facility. He hears word that the military has arrived and is the only chance of escape, but this is a cruel lie. The military is here to cover up the experiments being done at Black Mesa and kill employees on sight. Even after he reaches the surface, it is a wartorn hellscape with bombings leaving Black Mesa a pock-marked wasteland. He is forced back underground where it soon becomes clear that if the Resonance Cascade is not stopped, there will be no world left to escape to. The story continues on unweakened until the game ends with a climactic choice. This choice gives no true answers, leaving the player hungry for more knowledge about the Black Mesa Incident. While intriguing and satisfying taken as a solo experience, this ending also does an excellent job generating interest for a Half-Life 2.

	Of course, such a story would be of no consequence if Half-Life’s gameplay was poor. Luckily, it inherited the fluid control of Quake, whose idTech 2 engine had been modified to produce Half-Life’s own GoldSrc. The movement in the game is buttery smooth and delicate, with the notable exception of ladder climbing. Airstrafes and bunnyhops are also present in the game for those with interest in advanced movement techniques. The gunplay is solid and boasts a wide selection of weapons with unique uses. From the group damaging grenade to the close range shotgun to the point-and-click tau cannon. In addition, encounters are built to be asymmetric and unique, meaning that very few firefights in the game feel similar. The difficulty level does not result in very many game overs, but continuously deprives the player of resources and keeps them on edge. Taken together, this weapon variety, encounter design, and difficulty level make for a tactical depth absent in many of today’s big releases, let alone Half-Life’s contemporaries.

	Half-Life not only revolutionized the First Person Shooter genre, but can be seen as popularizing the idea that action games should have just as good a story as any adventure game. In the following years, other games agreeing with Half-life’s storytelling philosophy would come along to critical and commercial success, such as Halo, Gears of War, and Uncharted. The idea that good gameplay and good story were mutually exclusive was debunked by Half-life’s immense success and lasting legacy.

	The game holds up to this day and I strongly recommend anyone interested in first person shooters buy and play it.

Looking back on Half-Life, many believe it to be some sort of gaming Holy Grail. It was influential in shaping the first person shooter genre; taking bold steps in terms of level design, gameplay mechanics and dynamic storytelling. 

Taking the role of theoretical physicist Gordon Freeman, you are tasked with making it out of the Black Mesa research facility when you and your colleagues accidentally unleash an alien invasion. The enemies you encounter are numerous and varied; from the slow but eerie alien headcrabs to the ruthless government agents who are sent in to keep the situation contained. The action takes you from claustrophobic laboratories to large open environments. Each encounter feels fresh and exciting and the pacing is perfect: with large scale battles broken up with exploration. 

With not cutscenes and limited interaction with characters who are not hostile the story is delivered non-invasively through details in the environment. For players who are keen on rich characterisation and story driven epics they may feel disappointed, especially when comparing Half-Life to its sequels. However, for players who enjoy uninterrupted shooting sprees, Half-Life will be a pleasant addition to their library, even though most first person shooter fans will have played it already.

By contemporary standards Half-Life may seem rudimentary however the robust gameplay mechanics, fun gunplay and unique setting still make it a fun experience and a must have for any first person shooter fan.

nothing ventured, nothing gained

It was very interesting to play a game that had inspired so much. I honestly enjoyed this game. Ignoring the style of graphics that were common for the time period that this game came out, it ran quite well. There were a few loading problems when the loading screens came up as I progressed through the game. It was a suprisingly long game, which I enjoyed. It had a good amount of puzzles and was challenging in various ways, although it is quite simple to grasp the concept and controls. The controls were simple and easy to use. It was pretty simple to play and I progressed through the game with little trouble. The storyline was interesting and captures attention well. Overall, I found the game enjoyable and would recommend it.

Un classico.

When this game first came out, it was, for many, the most awesome thing that could ever happen. Half-Life is a classic FPS and has a lot nostalgic value. The game which holds up even today.

Good things in Half-Life:
- Classic game which (most likely) every gamer has at least tried
- Quite a long game, which just doesn't suddenly stop
- It can be difficult but ain't nowhere near impossible and frustration
- Good library of mods

Bad things in Half-Life:
- Might not be a good choice if you are a bit younger and want a realistic-looking FPS. It's a old game with old graphics.
- Enemy AI can be very stupid sometimes
- There's not that many different enemies

I would recommend this for older gamers who have experience in old games. Also this game suits for those who seeks treasures from past.
I wouldn't recommend this game for those who wants awesome new graphics and realistic physics.

Points: 7 / 10 (..as a HL-fan I'll give 9.7/10)

Never break first person perspective so you stand and listen to NPC dialogue or dont. YOU are Freeman
